choices.text: Stop MDT give thalidomide
Stop MDT, start systemic corticosteroids
Continue MDT, start systemic steroids

questions.text: In a case where a patient undergoing multi-drug therapy (MDT) experiences a deterioration of existing lesions and nerve complications, what course of action would you consider taking next? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Continue MDT, start systemic steroids

 

The situation described, where pre-existing lesions worsen during multi-drug therapy (MDT) for leprosy, indicates a type 1 lepra reaction. In managing this condition, the recommended approach would be to continue MDT while initiating systemic steroid treatment.

 

  • Type 1 lepra reactions are marked by inflammation of existing skin lesions, leading to symptoms such as edema, redness, and pain. While ulcers are uncommon, the development of new lesions is exceptionally rare. Additionally, acute neuritis may occur, presenting with tenderness and impairment of both motor and sensory functions.
  • In patients with lepra reactions, MDT is never discontinued. NSAIDs and oral steroids can be added to treat pain.
  • Thalidomide is considered the gold standard for treating severe cases of type-2 lepra reaction or erythema nodosum leprosum. However, it is not the Drug of Choice due to its high cost and potential for adverse drug reactions. In type II lepra reactions, patients may experience systemic symptoms such as iritis, orchitis, and the appearance of new skin lesions.

 

Type I & II lepra reactions:

 

(ENL = Erythema Nodosum Leprosum)

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Stop MDT give thalidomide

  • Thalidomide is an immunomodulatory drug that may be used in certain conditions, like leprosy and its complications.
  • However, stopping MDT is not recommended as it is crucial to continue the treatment of the primary disease. Thalidomide is not used as treatment for Type 1 lepra reaction in leprosy.

 

Option B. Continue MDT, start thalidomide –

While MDT should be continued, thalidomide is not typically used for nerve complications. It's used primarily for severe or recurrent erythema nodosum leprosum (ENL) Type 2 Lepra reaction, which is an immune-mediated complication of leprosy.

 

Option C. Stop MDT, start systemic corticosteroids –

  • Stopping MDT is not advised as the antibiotics in MDT are essential for treating the bacterial infection causing the disease.
  • The MDT should be continued to prevent the development of drug resistance and to adequately treat the underlying infection.

 

Option D. Continue MDT, start systemic steroids -

  • This is the correct management for a leprosy patient with nerve damage, which is likely due to an immune reaction called a leprosy reaction. Systemic corticosteroids are used to control the inflammation and prevent further nerve damage.
  • MDT should be continued to treat the underlying infection.
  • The reason for selecting option D is that systemic corticosteroids are effective in treating acute nerve inflammation and can prevent further damage while continuing MDT ensures that the infection is adequately treated.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the case of nerve complications in a patient undergoing multi-drug therapy for conditions like leprosy, the appropriate course of action is to continue the anti-microbial therapy and start systemic steroids to manage the inflammatory reaction causing nerve damage.

 

Reference:  Rook's Textbook of Dermatology -9th Edition Chapter 28 Page no 28.5, 28.12, 28.16

choices.text: Iron is converted from ferrous to ferric form before absorption through apical membrane.
Apoferritin is the storage form.
Iron is transported via transferrin in the blood.
Ascorbic acid helps in iron reabsorption.

questions.text: Which one of the following is incorrect about iron transport? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Iron is converted from ferrous to ferric form before absorption through apical membrane.

 

Iron metabolism involves complex processes where iron must be in the correct oxidation state to be absorbed and utilized effectively by the body. Iron in the diet is primarily found in the ferric (Fe3+) form, but for it to be absorbed across the apical membrane of enterocytes in the intestine, it needs to be converted into the ferrous (Fe2+) form. This conversion is crucial because only ferrous iron can be effectively transported into the cells. The statement in option A is incorrect because it suggests the opposite process—conversion from ferrous to ferric—before absorption, which is not accurate. The conversion actually goes from ferric (Fe3+) to ferrous (Fe2+) before iron is absorbed.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Apoferritin is the storage form: This statement is correct. Apoferritin binds with iron to form ferritin, which is the storage form of iron within cells.

 

Option C. Iron is transported via transferrin in the blood: This is also correct. After iron is absorbed into the bloodstream, it binds to the protein transferrin, which transports it to various tissues, including the bone marrow for hemoglobin production.

 

Option D. Ascorbic acid helps in iron reabsorption: This statement is true. Ascorbic acid (vitamin C) reduces ferric iron (Fe3+) to ferrous iron (Fe2+), which enhances its absorption in the intestine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Iron must be converted from ferric (Fe3+) to ferrous (Fe2+) form for effective absorption through the apical membrane of enterocytes

questions.text: A patient presented with complaint of a jaw swelling. His tissue was found to have the presence of t (8;14). The histopathological appearance of the bone marrow aspirate tissue is given in the image. Which of the following is a likely diagnosis for this patient? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Burkitt lymphoma 

 

The presence of a translocation t(8;14) is characteristic of Burkitt’s lymphoma. The same is confirmed by the tumor cells with cytoplasmic vacuolation and distinct nucleoli.

 

Direct lines from Robbins.. - ”When the bone marrow is involved, aspirates reveal tumor cells with slightly clumped nuclear chromatin, two to five distinct nucleoli, and royal blue cytoplasm containing clear cytoplasmic vacuoles”.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Follicular lymphoma: Characterized by t(14;18) translocation and involves BCL2 gene, not typically presenting with jaw swelling.

 

Option C. Acute myeloid leukemia (AML): Does not involve t(8;14) translocation and has different histopathological features.

 

Option D. Multiple myeloma: Plasma cell neoplasm, typically presents with bone pain, anemia, renal dysfunction, and hypercalcemia, not with t(8;14) translocation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Burkitt lymphoma is identified by the presence of the t(8;14) translocation and histopathological features including cells with cytoplasmic vacuolation and distinct nucleoli. It commonly presents with jaw or abdominal tumors and requires prompt recognition and treatment due to its aggressive nature.

questions.text: Which enzyme is shared between the pathways for cholesterol and ketone body synthesis? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) HMG-CoA Synthase

 

Explanation:

 

HMG-CoA Synthase is an enzyme shared between both cholesterol biosynthesis and ketone body formation. In both pathways, HMG-CoA synthase catalyzes the condensation of acetoacetyl-CoA with another molecule of acetyl-CoA to form 3-hydroxy-3-methylglutaryl-CoA (HMG-CoA). However, there are two different isoforms of this enzyme: a cytosolic form involved in cholesterol synthesis and a mitochondrial form involved in ketogenesis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. HMG-CoA Reductase: CoA Reductase is the rate-limiting enzyme in cholesterol synthesis, converting HMG-CoA to mevalonate, but is not involved in ketone body synthesis.

 

Option B. HMG-CoA Lyase: CoA Lyase is specific to the ketogenesis pathway, where it cleaves HMG-CoA to form acetoacetate and acetyl-CoA. It is not involved in cholesterol synthesis.

 

Option D. Thiokinase: (also called acyl-CoA synthetase) activates fatty acids for metabolism by forming fatty acyl-CoA, but is not directly involved in either cholesterol synthesis or ketogenesis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Although cholesterol synthesis and ketogenesis are separate pathways occurring in different cellular compartments (cytosol vs. mitochondria), they share a common step involving HMG-CoA synthase, which catalyzes the formation of HMG-CoA in both processes.

questions.text: A patient presents in emergency department with sudden hematemesis. He has been taking aspirin for his arthritis and drinks alcohol occasionally. He gives a history of occasional abdominal pain. On examination, there is no abdominal mass or tenderness. What is the likely diagnosis?(NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Peptic ulcer

 

  • This patient most likely has a bleeding peptic ulcer.
  •  Peptic ulcer disease (PUD) includes both gastric and duodenal ulcers.
  •  Aspirin, an NSAID, interferes with the protective role of prostaglandins on the gastric and duodenal mucosa, increasing the risk of peptic ulcer formation in the stomach and the duodenum.
  •  Common presentations of peptic ulcers include pain in the epigastrium, bleeding, and vomiting.
  • The history of aspirin use and alcohol consumption further supports the diagnosis of a peptic ulcer.

 

Peptic Ulcer Disease (PUD)

 

  • Etiology: Helicobacter pylori infection and NSAID use.
  • Mechanism: NSAIDs like aspirin disrupt the protective mucosal layer, leading to ulcer formation.
  • Symptoms: Epigastric pain, hematemesis, melena.
  • Sequelae:
    • Bleeding (more common in duodenal ulcers)
    • Perforation leading to peritonitis
    • Stricture causing gastric outlet obstruction
    • Malignancy risk (only in gastric ulcers)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mallory-Weiss:

 

  • Occurs following repeated vomiting or retching, often associated with an alcoholic binge.
  • Characterized by mucosal lacerations at the gastroesophageal junction.
  • Presents with self-limiting hematemesis, not usually profuse.

 

Option B. Esophagitis:

 

  • Inflammation of the esophagus, often due to gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD).
  • Results in chronic blood loss and commonly presents as anemia rather than sudden hematemesis.
  • Symptoms include heartburn, regurgitation, and dysphagia.

 

Option D. Esophageal varices:

 

  • Dilated submucosal veins in the lower esophagus, often due to portal hypertension.
  • Common in patients with liver cirrhosis.
  • Presents with massive hematemesis, splenomegaly, and ascites, none of which are described in this patient.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Peptic ulcer disease (PUD) is a common cause of sudden hematemesis, especially in patients with risk factors such as NSAID use (e.g., aspirin) and occasional alcohol consumption.
  • Recognition of these risk factors is crucial in diagnosing and managing PUD effectively.

questions.text:
What is the antidote of cyanide poisoning? (INICET MAY 2024)

 

A. Amyl Nitrite
B. Sodium Nitrite
C. Sodium Thiosulphate
D. Benzyl Thiocyanate
E. Sodium Nitroprusside
questions.solution:
Ans. A) ABC

 

Cyanide poisoning inhibits cytochrome C oxidase, a key enzyme in the mitochondrial electron transport chain, leading to cellular hypoxia and lactic acidosis. The treatment for cyanide poisoning involves agents that either bind to cyanide, facilitating its excretion, or convert it into a less toxic form.

 

A. Amyl Nitrite and B. Sodium Nitrite: These compounds oxidize hemoglobin to methemoglobin, which has a higher affinity for cyanide than cytochrome C oxidase. This process frees cytochrome C oxidase and forms cyanmethemoglobin.

 

C. Sodium Thiosulphate: This compound acts directly by converting cyanmethemoglobin to thiocyanate, which is less toxic and is excreted in the urine. Additionally, it directly breaks the bond between cytochrome C oxidase and cyanide.

 

D. Benzyl Thiocyanate: This is not a recognized treatment for cyanide poisoning and does not have the properties needed to detoxify cyanide.

 

E. Sodium Nitroprusside: This compound, while containing cyanide groups, is not used as an antidote for cyanide poisoning. It is actually a source of cyanide and is used for different medical purposes, such as vasodilation in hypertensive emergencies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The main antidotes for cyanide poisoning include amyl nitrite, sodium nitrite, and sodium thiosulphate. These agents work by either converting cyanide into a less toxic form or by forming methemoglobin which binds to cyanide, freeing cytochrome C oxidase.

questions.text:
A 16-year-old girl with primary amenorrhea has the following features. What is the most probable diagnosis? (NEET PG 2018)

 

  • Normal stature
  • Thelarche - absent
  • FSH, LH - high
  • Karyotype - 46 XX
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Gonadal dysgenesis

 

Explanation:

 

The probable diagnosis in this case is pure gonadal dysgenesis. Primary amenorrhea with absent secondary sexual characteristics (thelarche) and high levels of FSH and LH indicate hypergonadotropic hypogonadism, which suggests an ovarian cause. The karyotype 46 XX confirms gonadal dysgenesis.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Testicular feminizing syndrome/Androgen Insensitivity Syndrome

 

  • This condition occurs in individuals with a 46 XY karyotype.
  • Individuals with this syndrome have absent uterus and ovaries and exhibit secondary sexual development, especially breast development, due to peripheral production of estrogens.

 

Option C. Kallmann Syndrome

 

  • This is a cause of hypogonadotropic hypogonadism leading to primary amenorrhea.
  • It is associated with anosmia and absent secondary sexual characteristics.
  • FSH and LH levels are low in this condition.

 

Option D. Turner Syndrome

 

  • Characterized by a 45 XO karyotype.
  • Individuals have streak ovaries leading to low estrogen levels and absent secondary sexual characteristics.
  • FSH and LH levels are high.
  • A very important feature is short stature, which is not seen in the patient described.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Primary amenorrhea with high FSH and LH levels and a 46 XX karyotype indicates gonadal dysgenesis.

 

Ref: Page no 454, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology, 6th edition

questions.text: Viral infection causing transient aplastic anemia is: (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Parvovirus B-19

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Parvovirus B19 infection targets erythroid cell lines, particularly the pronormoblast stage, and is known to cause transient aplastic anemia, particularly in patients with underlying hemolytic disorders, as well as other clinical manifestations such as erythema infectiosum, arthritis, and non-immune fetal hydrops.

questions.text: A patient suffering from leprosy develops a dirty wound on his foot. What is the next step in management? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Debride and dressing

 

The image shows a lower limb ulcer in a patient with a history of leprosy. This type of ulcer is typically neuropathic or trophic due to nerve damage caused by leprosy, leading to decreased sensation and subsequent injury. The first and most crucial step in managing such ulcers is debridement and proper dressing. Debridement removes necrotic tissue, slough, and any other debris, which promotes a clean wound environment conducive to healing. Proper dressing keeps the ulcer protected and aids in healing by maintaining an optimal moisture balance.

 

Subsequent steps after debridement include appropriate foot care, offloading pressure from the affected area, and limb rehabilitation to prevent recurrence. However, the immediate next step is to clean the wound, making debridement and dressing the correct initial intervention.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Start MDT: Multi-drug therapy (MDT) is the treatment for leprosy to address the underlying infection but does not directly contribute to the healing of an existing ulcer. While MDT is crucial for treating leprosy, it does not manage the wound directly and should not be the first step in ulcer management.

 

Option C. Foot care, limb rehabilitation: Foot care and rehabilitation are essential components of managing neuropathic ulcers, especially in preventing further injuries and recurrences. However, these measures alone will not heal an existing dirty or necrotic ulcer. The ulcer must be cleaned and dressed first before these steps can be effective.

 

Option D. Deformity correction: This will help in healing of ulcer at a later stage.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the management of a neuropathic or trophic ulcer in a leprosy patient, the first step should be debridement and dressing to clean the wound. This is followed by comprehensive foot care and rehabilitation to support healing and prevent recurrence.

questions.text: A 10-year-old male child complains of mild painful swelling over the scalp for 3 months as shown in the image below. He also has a pet dog at his home. What is the diagnosis of the given condition? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Kerion

 

  • The case of a young boy coming into contact with a zoophilic organism and displaying symptoms of a boggy inflammatory mass, accompanied by thick crusting and matting of hair, indicates a possible diagnosis of kerion.
  • Kerion is an intense inflammatory form of tinea capitis, caused by dermatophytes that have an affinity for animals (pet dog clue).

 

Tinea capitis variants:

 

 

Kerion:

 

 

  • Lesion: Boggy indurated scalp swelling
  • Easily pluckable hair associated with regional lymphadenopathy
  • Most common causative organisms - T. verrucosum and T. mentagrophytes.
  • Investigation: 10% KOH mount

 

Treatment: DOC overall and for Microsporum à Griseofulvin

 

Note: DOC for Trichophyton à Terbinafine.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Furuncle:

  • Description: Also known as a boil, a furuncle is a deep folliculitis, an infection of the hair follicle.
  • Reason for exclusion from the diagnosis: Furuncles are typically more localized and painful and would not be described as "boggy." Also, they don’t have a direct association with having a pet dog.

 

Option B. Epidermoid cyst:

  • Description: These are benign cysts originating from the epidermis. They are filled with keratin and have a characteristic central punctum as seen in the image below.

 

 

  • Reason for exclusion from the diagnosis: Epidermoid cysts are typically non-painful unless infected. They do not usually present as boggy swellings and are not related to having a pet.

 

Option D. Folliculitis:

  • Description: Folliculitis is the inflammation or infection of one or more hair follicles.
  • Reason for exclusion from the diagnosis: Folliculitis on the scalp would typically present as multiple small, itchy, and red pustules. It wouldn't create a boggy swelling as described in the question.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Kerion is a boggy, tender scalp swelling associated with hair loss and potentially linked to animal exposure, indicative of a fungal infection rather than a bacterial cause like furuncle or folliculitis, or a benign lesion such as an epidermoid cyst.

 

Reference: 

 

Rook's Textbook of Dermatology 9th Edition Page no 26.22, 26.23-26.24, 32.38, 32.39, 32.40, 90.27, 108.11

questions.text: A patient with suicidal tendency ingested some substance. He presents with tachycardia, dilated pupil, and hypertension. Identify the drug. (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cocaine

 

The patient's symptoms—tachycardia, dilated pupils, and hypertension—are indicative of a sympathomimetic toxidrome, which is most commonly caused by stimulants like cocaine. Cocaine is a potent sympathomimetic agent that stimulates the central nervous system, leading to increased heart rate (tachycardia), elevated blood pressure (hypertension), and mydriasis (dilated pupils). These clinical signs are classic for cocaine toxicity, especially in a setting involving substance use with suicidal intent.

 

Cocaine blocks the reuptake of norepinephrine, dopamine, and serotonin, leading to an excess of these neurotransmitters in the synaptic cleft, which accounts for the heightened sympathetic activity observed.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Heroin: Heroin is an opioid that typically causes miosis (constricted pupils), bradycardia, and respiratory depression. It does not fit the clinical presentation of dilated pupils, tachycardia, and hypertension, which are opposite of opioid effects.

 

Option C. Morphine: Morphine, like heroin, is an opioid that causes pupil constriction (miosis) rather than dilation. It also leads to decreased heart rate and blood pressure, contrasting the symptoms seen in this patient.

 

Option D. Chlorpheniramine: Chlorpheniramine is an antihistamine with anticholinergic properties that can cause pupil dilation and mild tachycardia, but it is less likely to cause significant hypertension. Furthermore, chlorpheniramine is not commonly associated with substance abuse for suicidal intent.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cocaine toxicity is characterized by sympathetic overdrive symptoms such as tachycardia, dilated pupils, and hypertension, making it the likely substance in cases of suspected sympathomimetic drug overdose.

questions.text: Which of the following fruits is the richest source of Vitamin C? [NEET PG 2015]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Guava

 

  • Guava contains 212 mg of Vitamin C per 100g, making it the richest source among the given options. This is significantly higher than oranges, which contain only 68 mg per 100g. 
  • The hierarchy of Vitamin C content in fruits places Amla (Indian Gooseberry) at the top, followed by Guava, and then citrus fruits like oranges.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Orange: Contains 68 mg of Vitamin C per 100g, which is considerably less than

 

Option C. Strawberry: Not listed with specific Vitamin C values in the nutritional tables of common fruits.

 

Option D. Kiwi: Not listed with specific Vitamin C values in the nutritional tables of common fruits.

 

Educational Objective:

 

While Amla (Indian Gooseberry) is actually the richest natural source of Vitamin C (600 mg/100g), among the common fruits listed in the question options, guava stands out as an exceptionally rich non-citrus source of Vitamin C with more than three times the content found in oranges.

choices.text: It is a mitochondrial storage disorder

questions.text: An 8-year-old child has difficulty walking and getting up from a squatting position. A muscle biopsy was done and is as shown in the image. Which of the following is true about this condition? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Death occurs in 3rd decade

 

The clinical scenario and the muscle biopsy showing fatty replacement of muscle fibers are suggestive of Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD). Death in DMD occurs in the late teens and 20s (3rd decade).

 

 

Gower sign:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Previous history of viral prodrome: This option is not correct. DMD is a genetic disorder and does not typically have a history of a viral prodrome.

 

Option C. It is a mitochondrial storage disorder: This option is incorrect. DMD is not a mitochondrial storage disorder; it is caused by mutations in the dystrophin gene.

 

Option D. Early treatment has excellent prognosis: While early treatment with corticosteroids can help manage symptoms and slow disease progression, DMD remains a progressive and fatal disease with current treatments. Thus, early treatment does not lead to an "excellent" prognosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD) is a genetic disorder characterized by progressive muscle weakness, and death typically occurs in the late teens to early 20s.

choices.text: Investing layer of deep cervical fascia

questions.text: A patient presents with swelling below the left earlobe and is experiencing pain. What is the most likely cause of this pain? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Greater auricular nerve

 

The greater auricular nerve is a sensory nerve that supplies the skin of the external ear, the area over the parotid gland, and the angle of the mandible. It is a branch of the cervical plexus, specifically arising from the cervical spinal nerves C2 and C3. Any acute inflammation of the gland such as acute sialadenitis results in pain in the preauricular region. The pain is mainly due to stretching of the capsule resulting in stimulation of the greater auricular nerve.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Facial nerve: The facial nerve (cranial nerve VII) traverses through the parotid gland but does not innervate it. Instead, it provides motor innervation to the muscles of facial expression. Damage to the facial nerve may lead to facial paralysis or weakness, but it's not directly responsible for sensation or pain below the earlobe.

 

Option B. Investing layer of deep cervical fascia: This is a layer of connective tissue that envelops the neck and extends into the face. It surrounds several structures, including the parotid gland. While the fascia itself isn't directly responsible for sensation, inflammation or infections that cause stretching of this fascia might contribute to discomfort.

 

Option C. Auriculotemporal nerve: This is a branch of the mandibular division of the trigeminal nerve (V3). It provides sensory innervation to the skin above the parotid gland, the external ear, and the external auditory canal. Though it provides sensation to the aforementioned areas, the region described in the scenario (below the earlobe) is not primarily innervated by the auriculotemporal nerve.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Greater auricular nerve originates from the cervical plexus, specifically from the C2 and C3 spinal nerves. It ascends to the parotid gland and provides sensory innervation to the skin over the parotid gland, the earlobe, and the area behind the ear, so the greater auricular nerve is most directly responsible for transmitting pain sensations from these regions.

questions.text: Which of the following pairings of trace element deficiencies and their clinical syndromes is incorrectly matched? [NEET PG 2017]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Zinc - Night Blindness

 

  • This pairing is incorrectly matched. Night blindness (nyctalopia) is primarily associated with Vitamin A deficiency, not zinc deficiency. 
  • Zinc deficiency manifests with different clinical presentations including growth retardation, delayed wound healing, hypogonadism, decreased taste acuity (hypogeusia), alopecia, and skin lesions. 
  • While zinc plays a role in vitamin A metabolism, it is not directly responsible for night blindness.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Fluoride - Dental caries: This is correctly matched. Fluoride deficiency is associated with increased susceptibility to dental caries. Fluoride strengthens tooth enamel by converting hydroxyapatite to fluorapatite, which is more resistant to acid dissolution.

 

Option C. Chromium - Glucose intolerance: This is correctly matched. Chromium is an essential component of glucose tolerance factor (GTF) which enhances insulin action. Chromium deficiency can lead to impaired glucose tolerance, which presents as symptoms similar to diabetes mellitus.

 

Option D. Selenium - Cardiomyopathy: This is correctly matched. Selenium deficiency is associated with Keshan disease, a cardiomyopathy first identified in selenium-deficient regions of China. Selenium functions as part of antioxidant enzymes (glutathione peroxidase) that protect cellular components from oxidative damage.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Trace element deficiencies present with specific clinical syndromes based on their biochemical roles in the body; night blindness is specifically a manifestation of Vitamin A deficiency rather than zinc deficiency, though zinc plays supporting roles in vitamin A metabolism and transport.

questions.text: 60-year-old obese lady underwent cholecystectomy. After 3 days she develops respiratory distress. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Pulmonary embolism

 

Explanation

 

The patient, an obese post-operative case following cholecystectomy, presents with respiratory distress three days after surgery. This is highly suggestive of a pulmonary embolism, particularly in the context of immobilization and the hypercoagulable state following surgery. Pulmonary embolism is a common and serious complication of deep vein thrombosis (DVT), which can occur due to immobilization and endothelial injury during surgery.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Air embolism: This is less likely in this scenario as it typically occurs immediately during or after surgical procedures involving vascular access.

 

Option C. Atelectasis: While atelectasis can cause respiratory distress post-operatively, it typically does not cause sudden severe symptoms three days post-op.

 

Option D. Myocardial Infarction: Although possible, the context of recent surgery and immobilization makes pulmonary embolism a more likely diagnosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In post-operative patients, particularly those who are obese and immobilized, the development of sudden respiratory distress should raise suspicion for pulmonary embolism due to the increased risk of deep vein thrombosis and subsequent embolization. Prompt diagnosis and management are crucial.

 

Note - The rule of threes (in Immobilization) whenever the patient is immobilized for more than 72 hours/ >3 days in the last 3 months that is called significant immobilization and that increases the risk of DVT and pulmonary embolism.

questions.text: Green birefringence on polarized light in amyloid is observed on? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A. Congo Red staining

 

Explanation:

 

Amyloid deposits stained with Congo red show characteristic apple green birefringence when examined under polarized microscopy. This optical property occurs due to the β-pleated sheet configuration of amyloid fibrils, which creates a specific pattern of light refraction. Congo red is one of the most definitive histological stains for the identification of amyloid in tissues, making it a critical diagnostic tool for amyloidosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. X-Ray Crystallography - X-ray crystallography is used to determine the three-dimensional structure of proteins including amyloid fibrils. While it can confirm the β-pleated sheet structure of amyloid, it doesn't produce green birefringence as it's an analytical technique rather than a histological stain.

 

Option C. Infrared Spectroscopy - This analytical technique identifies chemical compounds based on how infrared radiation is absorbed or reflected. It can be used to study amyloid composition but doesn't generate any birefringence effect as it's not a histological staining method.

 

Option D. Von-Kossa - Von-Kossa staining is specifically used to demonstrate deposits of calcium or calcium salts in tissues. The calcium appears black with this stain and does not show birefringence under polarized light. It has no utility in detecting amyloid.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Green birefringence under polarized light after Congo Red staining is a hallmark diagnostic feature of amyloid deposits and reflects the unique β-pleated sheet configuration of amyloid proteins.

questions.text: Implantation of the embryo takes place how many days after fertilization? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 8


Implantation of the embryo typically starts around 5 to 6 days after fertilization and is usually completed by 8 to 9 days. After fertilization, the embryo undergoes several stages of development, including cleavage and blastocyst formation. The blastocyst travels down the fallopian tube and reaches the uterus by around day 5. It then begins to attach to and invade the uterine lining, completing the implantation process by around day 8. Therefore, 8 days is the most accurate answer representing the completion of the implantation process.

 

 

Educational Objective:


Implantation of the embryo begins around day 5 to 6 and is completed by day 8 to 9 after fertilization.

questions.text: Identify the type of knot seen in the image given below:
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Reef knot

 

The image shows a reef knot, also called as square knot:

  • It is the most Basic Surgical Knot
  • Two Throws in “Opposite Directions”

 

Other Surgical knots

 

Granny Knot

  • Two Throws in the Same Direction
  • Not as Strong as Square Knot – Can Slip

 

 

 

 

Option C: Surgeon’s Knot

  • Initial Throw is Pulled Through Twice
  • Second Throw in Opposite Direction
  • More Stable than a Square Knot

 

 

Option A: Surgical Slip Knot (Double Half-Hitch)

  • Keeping Tension on One End the Initial Knot is Thrown Twice in the Same Direction and then Pulled Tight
    • Essentially a “Purposeful” Granny Knot
  • Following Throws in Opposite Directions to Lock
  • Allows Initial Tightening of the Knot to Ensure Tightness

 

Other Options :

 

 

 

Educational Objective: The reef knot has

 

  • Two Throws in “Opposite Directions”

questions.text: Which of the following amino acids are necessary for purine ring formation? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Glycine, aspartate, glutamine

 

Explanation

 

Purine ring formation requires the amino acids glycine, aspartate, and glutamine.

 

These three amino acids provide crucial nitrogen and carbon atoms that are incorporated into the purine ring structure during its biosynthesis. Specifically, glycine contributes carbon and nitrogen, aspartate contributes a nitrogen, and glutamine provides another nitrogen atom. This combination is essential for the complex two-ring structure of purines.

 

In contrast, pyrimidine rings, which have a single-ring structure, require only aspartate and glutamine for their formation.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Glycine, aspartate, valine: Valine is not involved in purine synthesis. Valine is a branched-chain amino acid used primarily in protein synthesis and energy production.

 

Option C. Glycine, aspartate, glutamate: Glutamate does not participate in purine ring formation. Glutamate is primarily involved in amino acid metabolism and neurotransmitter synthesis.

 

Option D. D. Glycine, aspartate, alanine: Alanine is not involved in purine ring formation. It is a non-essential amino acid involved in protein synthesis and glucose metabolism, but it does not contribute to the nitrogen or carbon framework of purines.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Important one liner

  • AA for Purines - Aspartate, Glutamine, Glycine
  • AA for Pyrimidines - Aspartate, Glutamine
  • Sources of N & C of Urea - CO2, Ammonia, Aspartate
  • AA linking Kreb's and Urea cycle - Aspartate
  • Molecule linking Kreb's and Urea cycle - Fumarate

questions.text: Which of the following is not a part of the Global Hunger Index? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Infant Mortality Rate

 

Explanation:

 

The Global Hunger Index is calculated based on the following indicators:

 

Till 2014 – following 3 indicators

 

 

After 2016, the Global Hunger Index calculation was done using above four indicators, which do not include the infant mortality rate directly.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. U5MR: Because the under-five mortality rate is one of the four indicators used in the calculation of the Global Hunger Index.

 

Option B. Malnutrition (wasting, stunting): Because both child wasting and child stunting are part of the four indicators used in the calculation of the Global Hunger Index.

 

Option C. Inadequate food supply: Because, while inadequate food supply can contribute to child undernourishment, it is not directly used as an indicator in the calculation of the Global Hunger Index.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Global Hunger Index is calculated using four indicators: child undernourishment, under-five mortality rate, child wasting, and child stunting. The infant mortality rate is not directly included in the calculation.

questions.text: What is the primary action of the superior oblique muscle? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Intorsion, Abduction, and Depression

 

The superior oblique muscle has three actions that can be remembered using the mnemonic "SOLID" where "SO" stands for Superior Oblique and "LID" stands for the three actions: Lateral (abduction), Intorsion, and Depression. The primary action of superior oblique is intorsion, the secondary action is depression, and the tertiary action is abduction. This functional pattern is consistent across all standard ophthalmology references.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Adduction, Intorsion, and Depression: This is incorrect because the superior oblique causes abduction, not adduction. Adduction is primarily the action of the medial rectus muscle.

 

Option C.Abduction, Extorsion, and Depression: This is incorrect because superior oblique causes intorsion, not extorsion. Extorsion is the action of the inferior oblique muscle.

 

Options D. Elevation, Intorsion, and Adduction: This is incorrect on two counts. Superior oblique causes depression (not elevation) and abduction (not adduction). Elevation is primarily the action of the superior rectus and inferior oblique muscles.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The superior oblique muscle primarily produces intorsion, with secondary action of depression and tertiary action of abduction (lateral movement). This can be remembered with the mnemonic "SOLID" (Superior Oblique - Lateral, Intorsion, Depression).

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy presents with bitemporal hemianopia. CT is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?(NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Craniopharyngioma

 

A calcified lesion in the suprasellar region suggests craniopharyngioma. It is derived from Rathke's pouch.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: Pituitary adenomas are seen in the sellar region in adults. Macroadenomas are seen as snowman or figure of eight appearance.

 

Option B: Meningioma is a supratentorial tumor, mainly in the parasagittal region. A classical Dural tail is seen.

 

Option D: Oligodendroglioma is exclusively found in the cerebral hemispheres, most commonly in the frontal lobes. Up to 90% of oligodendrogliomas contain visible calcification on CT.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Craniopharyngioma should be considered in young patients presenting with symptoms of visual field loss and a calcified suprasellar mass on imaging. This tumor's characteristic location and calcification are key diagnostic clues.

 

Reference– Grainger & Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition, Page No 742

questions.text: A female patient with dysphagia more for liquids in comparison to solids is likely to have which of the following finding in her barium swallow? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Smooth tapering of lower end

 

In achalasia cardia, there is a selective loss of inhibitory neurons in the lower esophagus, particularly affecting the lower esophageal sphincter. This neuronal loss leads to a characteristic radiological appearance of smooth tapering at the lower end of the esophagus, often referred to as the "bird beak" appearance. The patient experiences dysphagia, with more difficulty swallowing liquids compared to solids due to the impaired esophageal motility.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Irregular filling defect: Typically associated with other esophageal pathologies like tumors or strictures, not characteristic of achalasia.

 

Option B. Rat tail appearance: Classically associated with gastric carcinoma during barium studies. This sign indicates an infiltrative tumor at the pylorus or distal stomach, creating a narrowed, tapered appearance resembling a rat's tail. It is not a characteristic finding in esophageal disorders.

 

Option D. Corkscrew appearance: This radiological sign is typically seen in diffuse esophageal spasm. This is not a characteristic radiological feature of achalasia cardia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The radiological hallmark of achalasia cardia: smooth tapering of the lower esophageal end (bird beak appearance) due to loss of inhibitory neurons.

choices.text: Rigidity occurs in all the muscles of the body
Increase in the rate of discharge of the γ efferent neuron
Increased excitability of the motor neuron pool
Decerebration produces no phenomenon akin to spinal shock

questions.text: According to Herrington classification, the decerebrate rigidity is characterized by all except? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Rigidity occurs in all the muscles of the body

 

Explanation

 

Decerebrate rigidity is the rigid extension of all the limbs due to decerebration. This type of rigidity is well pronounced in the extensor muscles. The term decerebrate rigidity was coined by Sherrington in 1897.

 

Reason for decerebrate rigidity:

 

  • Release of the centers, situated below the section, from higher inhibitory controls. The inhibitory area is 4S. It is situated in the motor cortex of cerebrum, just anterior to area 4 and behind area 6. In this area, Betz cells are absent.
  • From here, the fibers are projected to spinal cord via reticular formation. So, in decerebration the discharge from neurons of area 4S cannot reach spinal motor neurons. This leads to exaggeration of spinal motor neurons resulting in rigidity.
  • Decerebrate rigidity is also produced by stopping the blood flow to the forebrain. It is done by occlusion of the common carotid artery and the basilar artery at the center of the pons.

 

Decerebrate rigidity is characterized by

 

  1. γ motor neuron discharge rate increased.
  2. Motor neuron pool excitability increased.
  3. Decerebration produces no phenomenon similar to spinal shock.
  4. Antigravity extensor muscles are involved in decerebrate injury

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Increase in the rate of discharge of the γ efferent neuron: Correct as part of the characterization of decerebrate rigidity. The increased discharge rate of the γ efferent neurons enhances the muscle spindle responses, contributing to increased muscle tone.

 

Option C. Increased excitability of the motor neuron pool: Correct, this increased excitability leads to the hyperactivity of motor neurons, particularly those controlling the extensor muscles.

 

Option D. Decerebration produces no phenomenon akin to spinal shock: Correct, unlike spinal shock, which involves a temporary reduction or loss of reflex activity below the level of a spinal cord injury, decerebration does not produce a similar transient reduction in reflexes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Decerebrate rigidity is characterized by an increase in extensor muscle tone due to enhanced activity of the γ motor neurons and increased excitability of the motor neuron pool, without inducing effects similar to spinal shock. Rigidity does not occur in all muscles of the body but is more pronounced in antigravity extensor muscles.

questions.text: In a patient with chronic renal failure, which of the following anesthetic drugs is contraindicated due to the risk of toxicity? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Pethidine

 

Pethidine (meperidine) is contraindicated in chronic renal failure due to the accumulation of its active metabolite, norpethidine. Norpethidine has a longer half-life than the parent drug and is neurotoxic, potentially causing seizures, tremors, agitation, and myoclonus. Since renal excretion is impaired in chronic kidney disease, norpethidine accumulates, increasing the risk of central nervous system toxicity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Morphine: Morphine does have active metabolites (notably morphine-6-glucuronide) that accumulate in renal failure, potentially leading to sedation and respiratory depression. However, it is not absolutely contraindicated—it can be used with dose adjustments and close monitoring.

 

Option B. Fentanyl: Fentanyl is the opioid of choice in renal impairment. It is metabolized in the liver and produces inactive metabolites, with minimal renal excretion, making it safe and predictable in patients with renal dysfunction.

 

Option D. Atracurium: Atracurium is a non-depolarizing neuromuscular blocker that undergoes Hofmann elimination (a temperature and pH-dependent degradation process) and ester hydrolysis, making it independent of renal or hepatic clearance. It is thus safe and preferred in renal failure, particularly during surgeries involving renal function.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Avoid pethidine in renal failure due to the risk of toxic metabolite accumulation. Opt for safer alternatives like fentanyl and atracurium, which have predictable pharmacokinetics and are less dependent on renal clearance.

choices.text: Transmission most commonly occurs during early gestation
Majority of fetuses are not infected even without any intervention
The risk of mother-to-child transmission can be reduced by elective cesarean section
The risk is related to the status of infection in the mother

questions.text: Which of the following statements about mother-to-child transmission (MTCT) of HIV is incorrect? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Transmission most commonly occurs during early gestation

 

HIV transmission from mother to child does not most commonly occur during early gestation. Vertical transmission primarily happens during labor and delivery or through breastfeeding. The intrapartum period represents the highest risk time for transmission, not early pregnancy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. is correct. Without any intervention, approximately 75% of infants born to HIV-positive mothers will not be infected. The natural transmission rate is about 25-30% without preventive measures.

 

Option C. is correct. Elective cesarean section significantly reduces mother-to-child transmission by minimizing fetal exposure to maternal blood and secretions during delivery. It's one of several interventions that can reduce transmission risk.

 

Option D. is correct. The risk of transmission is directly related to maternal viral load and disease status. Mothers with higher viral loads or advanced disease are more likely to transmit the virus to their infants.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

HIV vertical transmission occurs primarily during labor, delivery, and breastfeeding rather than early gestation, and can be significantly reduced through interventions including antiretroviral therapy, cesarean delivery, and avoidance of breastfeeding.

questions.text: The cross product ratio can be obtained by: [NEET PG 2019]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) Case control study

 

The cross-product ratio is a measure of association between two categorical variables, and it can be arrived at from a case-control study.

 

In a case-control study, the odds ratio (OR) is often used as a measure of association between the exposure and the outcome. The cross-product ratio is an alternative measure of association that can be derived from the odds ratio.

 

Interpretation

 

OR> 1 → Association Present

OR =1 → No Association

OR< 1 → Inverse/Negative Association → RF is protective(beneficial)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ecological study: This type of study examines the associations between exposure and outcomes at the population or group level, not at the individual level, and does not typically use the cross-product ratio.

 

Option B. Cohort study: This type of study follows a group of exposed and non-exposed individuals over time to observe the incidence of outcomes. It uses relative risk rather than the cross-product ratio.

 

Option C. Cross-sectional study: This study observes a population at a single point in time, assessing both exposure and outcome simultaneously. It can measure prevalence but not the cross-product ratio specifically.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The cross-product ratio, or odds ratio, is a measure of association commonly derived from case-control studies to determine the relationship between exposure and outcome.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male was on metronidazole therapy for a bacterial infection. He attended a party and consumed alcohol. Shortly after, he developed symptoms including intense facial flushing, severe nausea, vomiting, headache, dizziness, palpitations, and hypotension. What is the likely cause? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Drug interaction

 

The patient experienced a disulfiram-like reaction, which occurs due to the interaction between metronidazole and alcohol. Metronidazole inhibits the enzyme aldehyde dehydrogenase, which is responsible for metabolizing acetaldehyde, a byproduct of alcohol metabolism. When this enzyme is inhibited, acetaldehyde accumulates in the body, leading to symptoms such as facial flushing, nausea, vomiting, headache, dizziness, palpitations, and hypotension. This reaction is similar to what occurs with the drug disulfiram, which is used to deter alcohol consumption in people with alcohol dependence.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Metronidazole overdose: The symptoms described are not indicative of a metronidazole overdose. Overdose of metronidazole may cause different symptoms, including seizures and peripheral neuropathy, rather than the acute symptoms seen in this scenario.

 

Option B. Methanol poisoning: Methanol poisoning typically presents with symptoms like ataxia, severe sedation, and visual disturbances, which are not mentioned in this case. Methanol poisoning is also more commonly associated with ingestion of methanol, not the combination of alcohol with metronidazole.

 

Option D. Alcohol withdrawal: Alcohol withdrawal is characterized by symptoms such as tremors, agitation, seizures, and hallucinations, none of which are described in this scenario. Additionally, there is no history of alcohol dependence or cessation in the patient, making withdrawal an unlikely diagnosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Metronidazole can cause a disulfiram-like reaction when combined with alcohol, leading to the accumulation of acetaldehyde and subsequent unpleasant symptoms.

choices.text: Painless hematuria
Painful hematuria

questions.text: The most consistent and persistent feature of bladder carcinoma is: (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Painless hematuria

 

Bladder tumors classically produce painless hematuria. This is their dominant and sometimes only clinical manifestation. Frequency, urgency, and dysuria occasionally accompany the hematuria.

 

Bladder tumors produce a wide range of clinical features including:

 

  • Painless hematuria - classical feature and may be the only clinical manifestation
  • Irritative urinary symptoms (frequency, urgency, dysuria) - diffuse tumors or tumors at the bladder neck
  • Pyelonephritis or hydronephrosis - when the ureteral orifice is involved
  • Obstructive symptoms, palpable suprapubic mass, or lower extremity edema - late presentation with a large tumor mass
  • Weight loss and/or localized bone pain - metastatic disease

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Painful hematuria: This symptom, while possible, is less common and typically associated with other urological conditions.

 

Option C. Dysuria: Often occurs with more diffuse tumors or when the tumor is located at the bladder neck but is not as consistently observed as hematuria.

 

Option D. Suprapubic mass: Typically, a sign of advanced disease and not a consistent initial symptom.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Painless hematuria is the classical and most persistent feature of bladder carcinoma, often being the initial and sometimes the only symptom observed.

questions.text: Drug contraindicated in asthma in PPH (Postpartum Hemorrhage) case? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Carboprost

 

Carboprost is a prostaglandin F2 alpha analog that is commonly used to manage atonic postpartum hemorrhage by inducing strong uterine contractions. However, it is contraindicated in patients with asthma because it can cause bronchoconstriction and exacerbate asthma symptoms.

 

Carboprost is also contraindicated in patients with cardiac arrhythmias due to its potent cardiovascular effects.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Methyl ergometrine: This drug is used for the management of postpartum hemorrhage due to its uterotonic properties, but it does not specifically affect asthma and is not contraindicated in asthmatic patients.

 

Option C. Misoprostol: Misoprostol, a prostaglandin E1 analog, is also used in postpartum hemorrhage for uterine contraction. It does not have the same bronchoconstrictive effects as Carboprost and is not contraindicated in asthma.

 

Option D. Oxytocin: Oxytocin is a common uterotonic agent used in postpartum hemorrhage management. It has no known bronchoconstrictive properties and is safe for use in asthmatic patients.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Carboprost (PGF2 alpha) is contraindicated in patients with asthma due to its bronchoconstrictive effects.

questions.text: What is the mechanism of action of 5-alpha reductase?  (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Breakage of C4-C5 double bond

 

Explanation:

 

5-alpha reductase is an enzyme responsible for converting testosterone into dihydrotestosterone (DHT). This conversion occurs by the reduction of the double bond between the 4th and 5th carbon atoms in the A-ring of the steroid structure. The C4=C5 double bond is saturated by the addition of hydrogen atoms, transforming testosterone into DHT, which has higher affinity and potency at androgen receptors. This process plays a crucial role in the development of male external genitalia and secondary sexual characteristics.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Breakage of C–N bond: This bond is typically cleaved during reactions involving hydrolysis of peptide or amide structures, which is not relevant to steroid metabolism.

 

Option C. Breakage of amide bond: Amide bonds are found in proteins and peptides, not in steroid hormones like testosterone. Their cleavage is unrelated to the action of 5-alpha reductase.

 

Option D. Breakage of N–N bond: N–N bonds are uncommon in biological systems and are not involved in steroid hormone processing or the function of 5-alpha reductase.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

5-alpha reductase catalyzes the reduction of the C4–C5 double bond in testosterone, forming DHT and enhancing androgenic effects.

questions.text: A woman few months after delivery complains of bloody discharge from the nipple. What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ductal papilloma

 

Explanation:

 

In a young lactating woman with bloody nipple discharge:

 

  • Ductal papilloma is the most common cause of bloody nipple discharge in young women
  • It is a benign tumor arising from a single duct

 

Characteristics include:

 

  • Spontaneous discharge
  • Usually from single duct
  • May be serous or bloody
  • More common in young women
  • Diagnosed by ductoscopy
  • Treated by microdochectomy via tennis racket incision

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Duct ectasia: Incorrect as it typically causes greenish discharge and is associated with smoking

 

Option C. Galactocele: Incorrect as it presents as a swelling that may have milky discharge during lactation

 

Option D. Mondors disease: Incorrect as it is thrombophlebitis of superficial veins of breast/chest wall presenting as a cord-like tender structure, not nipple discharge

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ductal papilloma is the most common cause of bloody nipple discharge in young women, characterized by spontaneous discharge from a single duct.

choices.text: T cell receptor and MHC II

questions.text: All of the following interactions between T cells and APC (Antigen-Presenting Cell) are required for T cell activation/differentiation except: (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) PD-PDL1

 

PD-PDL1 interaction inhibits T cell activation and causes T cell exhaustion. It represents an immune checkpoint that suppresses T cell responses. This interaction is exploited by tumor cells to evade immune surveillance. 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. T cell receptor and MHC II 

 

  • This is a crucial first signal 1 (Antigen recognition) required for T cell activation
  • TCR recognize antigen presented by MHC molecules on APCs for initial activation
  • CD4+ T cells recognize MHC class II molecules, while CD8+ T cells recognize MHC class I molecules.

 

Option B. CD28 and CD80 

 

  • This acts as the essential co-stimulatory signal (Signal 2)
  • Without this second signal, T cells become anergic rather than activated
  • CD28 on T cells interacts with B7 molecules (CD80/86) on APCs

 

Option D. Cytokine secretion

 

  • Cytokine secretion is essential for T cell differentiation.
  • When there is interaction between CD40 of B cell with CD40 ligand of T cell, it leads to secretion of cytokines like IL-4 and IL-5 which are crucial for T cell differentiation.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

PD-PDL1 interaction is an inhibitory checkpoint that causes T cell exhaustion rather than activation. This pathway is important in cancer immunotherapy where checkpoint inhibitors are used to prevent tumor immune evasion.

questions.text: A young patient presents to the ophthalmic outpatient department with gradual blurring of vision in the left eye. Slit-lamp examination reveals fine stellate keratic precipitates, aqueous flare, and a typical complicated posterior subcapsular cataract. No posterior synechiae were observed. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Heterochromic Iridocyclitis of Fuch’s

 

Fuchs Heterochromic Iridocyclitis presents with a characteristic clinical picture that matches this case. The condition features fine stellate keratic precipitates distributed across the cornea and a low-grade anterior chamber inflammation with aqueous flare. A hallmark feature is the presence of posterior subcapsular cataract (PSC) as a complication. Most importantly, Fuchs specifically lacks posterior synechiae formation despite chronic inflammation, which is a distinguishing feature noted in this case.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Intermediate Uveitis (Pars Planitis): This condition primarily affects the ciliary body and vitreous rather than the anterior chamber. Its characteristic findings include "snowball" opacities in the vitreous and "snowbanking" at the ora serrata, not stellate keratic precipitates. Macular edema rather than PSC cataract would be the primary complication affecting vision.

 

Option B. Heerfordt's Disease: This is a specific manifestation of sarcoidosis presenting with uveitis, parotid gland enlargement, facial nerve palsy, and fever. Sarcoidosis typically causes granulomatous uveitis with "mutton fat" keratic precipitates rather than the stellate KPs described here, and posterior synechiae would typically form.

 

Option D. Subacute Iridocyclitis: This general term refers to an intermediate duration anterior uveitis. It would typically present with posterior synechiae formation, which is specifically absent in this case. Additionally, the characteristic stellate KPs described are specific to Fuchs.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The combination of stellate keratic precipitates, aqueous flare, posterior subcapsular cataract, and specifically the absence of posterior synechiae despite chronic inflammation strongly points to Fuchs Heterochromic Iridocyclitis, which follows the FUCHS mnemonic: Floaters, Unilateral uveitis, Complicated cataract, Heterochromia, Stellate KPs with Synechiae absent.

questions.text: A 5-year-old child presents with reduced hearing for the past 2-3 months. The otoscopy finding is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Serous Otitis media

 

Child presenting with hearing loss for the past 2-3 months with  air fluid levels on otoscopy is suggestive of serous otitis media.

 

Aetiology

 

  1. Eustachian tube block secondary to adenoid hyperplasia, chronic sinusitis or tonsillitis or rhinitis, palatal defects, tumors of nasopharynx
  2. Allergy
  3. Unresolved otitis media
  4. Viral infections – adeno and rhinovirus

 

Symptoms

 

The disease affects children of 5–8 years of age. The symptoms include:

 

  1. Conductive hearing loss.
  2. Delayed and defective speech. Because of hearing loss, development of speech is delayed or defective.
  3. Mild earaches.

 

Otoscopic Findings

 

  •  Tympanic membrane is often dull and opaque with loss of light reflex, and may appear yellow, grey or bluish in color.
  • Thin leash of blood vessels may be seen along the handle of malleus or at the periphery of tympanic membrane
  • Tympanic membrane may show varying degree of retraction. Sometimes, it may appear full or slightly bulging in its posterior part due to effusion.
  • Fluid level and air bubbles may be seen when fluid is thin and tympanic membrane transparent
  • Mobility of the tympanic membrane is restricted

 

Audiometry

 

  •  Pure tone audiometry shows conduction hearing loss
  •  Tympanometry will show B type curve

 

Treatment

 

1. Medical

 

  • Decongestants.
  • Antihistamines or sometimes steroids may be used in cases of allergy.
  • Antibiotics. They are useful in cases of upper respiratory tract infections or unresolved acute suppurative otitis media.
  • Middle Ear Aeration. Patients should repeatedly perform the Valsalva maneuver. Children can be given chewing gum to encourage repeated swallowing which opens the tube.

 

2. Surgical

 

  • Myringotomy and fluid aspiration
  • Grommet insertion
  • Tympanotomy and mastoidectomy
  • Surgical treatment of underlying causes like adenoid hypertrophy, tonsillar hypertrophy etc.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Myringitis bullosa involves the formation of blisters on the tympanic membrane due to inflammation, often associated with viral infections like influenza.

 

  • Symptoms: It is characterized by severe pain, occasionally hearing loss, and a rapid onset following an upper respiratory tract infection.
  • The symptoms of prolonged hearing loss and the otoscopic findings of fluid levels visible in the image are not typical for myringitis bullosa, which usually presents with acute, painful blistering rather than effusion.

Option C. Acute otitis media is an infection of the middle ear, typically of rapid onset, involving signs of acute infection such as ear pain, fever, and general malaise.

 

  • Symptoms: The tympanic membrane often appears red and bulging due to the presence of pus and fluid, and the condition is usually accompanied by significant pain and fever.
  • Why Not: The child's symptoms described do not include acute infectious signs like significant pain or fever, and the duration of hearing loss suggests a more chronic condition.

Option D. Pneumo Tympanum refers to the presence of air in the middle ear space, which is not typically associated with fluid. It can occur due to trauma, barotrauma, or as a rare complication of severe nasal congestion.

 

  • Symptoms: This condition might present with a feeling of fullness or popping in the ear but not with the fluid level and air bubbles typically seen in fluid accumulation conditions.
  • Why Not: The presence of air bubbles alongside fluid specifically points towards fluid accumulation rather than just air, making pneumo tympanum less likely in this scenario.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Serous otitis media requires comprehensive management to prevent long-term effects on hearing and speech development. Early intervention, both medical and surgical, is essential for restoring normal ear function and preventing recurrent episodes.

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 84

choices.text: MTP cannot be done as she has crossed 20 weeks
MTP can be done till 24 weeks
MTP can be done only if the mother's life is at risk
MTP can only be done if there is a substantial fetal anomaly

questions.text: A 14-year-old girl, a victim of rape, presents at 22 weeks for abortion. What advice will you give her? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans.  B)  MTP can be done till 24 weeks

 

The MTP Act of 2021 in India allows for abortions b/w 20- 24 weeks in specific cases, including:

 

  • Rape or sexual assault: The girl in the question is a victim of rape, which falls under this category.
  • Risk to maternal life or Disability: If continuing the pregnancy poses a significant risk to the mother's health or life.
  • Substantial fetal anomaly: If the fetus has severe abnormalities incompatible with life or causing significant disability.
  • Minors: The girl is 14 years old, making her a minor, and the law provides special considerations for them.
  • Change in marital status or humanitarian grounds: These are additional situations where MTP may be considered up to 24 weeks.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. MTP cannot be done as she has crossed 20 weeks: This is incorrect. While the general limit for MTP is 20 weeks, certain circumstances, like rape, allow for MTP up to 24 weeks.

 

Option C. MTP can be done only if the mother's life is at risk: This is partially correct. While risk to the mother's life is a valid reason, it's not the only one. Rape is also a valid indication for MTP up to 24 weeks.

 

Option D. MTP can only be done if there is a substantial fetal anomaly: Again, this is partially correct. Substantial fetal anomaly is one reason, but rape is another valid reason for MTP up to 24 weeks.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In India, under the MTP Act of 2021:

choices.text: Every acidic amino acid is essential.
Every basic amino acid is essential.
Every neutral amino acid is essential.
None of the statements are correct.

questions.text: Which one of the following assertions is correct? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) None of the statements are correct

 

Explanation:

 

The classification of amino acids as essential or non-essential is independent of their acidic, basic, or neutral properties. Essential amino acids cannot be synthesized in sufficient amounts by humans and must be obtained from the diet.

 

Looking at specific examples:

 

  • Acidic amino acids (aspartate and glutamate) are non-essential
  • Basic amino acids include arginine (semi-essential), lysine (essential), and histidine (semi-essential)
  • Neutral amino acids include both essential (valine, leucine, isoleucine) and non-essential (alanine, glycine) amino acids

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Every acidic amino acid is essential: This is incorrect. Acidic amino acids (glutamate and aspartate) are both non-essential as they can be synthesized from TCA cycle intermediates.

 

Option B. Every basic amino acid is essential: This is incorrect. While lysine is essential, arginine is semi-essential (some amount can be made in the body), and histidine is semi-essential (essential in children but not in adults).

 

Option C. Every neutral amino acid is essential: This is incorrect. Many neutral amino acids like alanine, serine, glycine, and proline are non-essential, while others like leucine and isoleucine are essential.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Amino acid classification by chemical property (acidic, basic, neutral) has no correlation with their nutritional classification (essential vs non-essential), with both essential and non-essential amino acids occurring across all chemical categories.

questions.text: A 24-year-old lactating female with an 18-month-old child comes with a history of irregular, heavy bleeding seeking contraceptive advice. Which is the contraceptive of choice? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) levonorgesterel IUD

 

Explanation:

 

  • Suitable during lactation
    • LNG-IUS is a progestin-only method
    • Does not reduce milk production (unlike estrogen-containing pills)
  • Controls heavy menstrual bleeding (menorrhagia)
    • LNG-IUS reduces menstrual blood loss by 70–90%
    • Improves hemoglobin levels and quality of life
  • Long-acting and reversible
    • Provides effective contraception for up to 5 years
    • Fertility returns quickly after removal
  • Low maintenance
    • No daily action required
    • Ideal for busy mothers with young children
  • High efficacy
    • Failure rate <0.2% per year
    • One of the most effective reversible methods
  • WHO Medical Eligibility Criteria (MEC)
    • Category 1 (no restriction) after 6 weeks postpartum
    • Safe for breastfeeding women
  • Fewer systemic side effects
    • Hormone acts locally in the uterus
    • Minimal systemic absorption

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Copper-T 380A: Copper-T 380A is a non-hormonal intrauterine device that may exacerbate heavy menstrual bleeding and would not be suitable for a patient already experiencing heavy bleeding.

 

Option C. Mala N: Mala N is also a possible contraceptive in this situation. There is high chance of non compliance and missed pill. LNG IUS is better option in such cases

 

Option D. Norethisterone enanthate - depot injection: Norethisterone enanthate is a progesterone-only injectable contraceptive. it may lead to delay in return to menses, and also requires follow up every 3 months for next dose, which is inconvenient.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For a lactating woman with a history of irregular and heavy menstrual bleeding, a combined oral contraceptive pill (COC) like Mala N is the preferred choice after the first 6 months postpartum as it helps regulate menstrual cycles and reduce menstrual flow.

 

Ref: Page no 398, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology, 7th edition

questions.text: Which type of hypersensitivity reaction is involved in the hyperacute rejection of renal transplants? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Type II

 

Hyperacute graft rejection is an example of type II hypersensitivity reaction.

 

It is mediated by preformed antibodies. It is a rare event that occurs in kidney transplantation.

 

This results in rapid, severe, and often irreversible damage to the transplanted kidney, leading to graft failure. The preformed antibodies are usually directed against specific antigens on the endothelial cells of the donor organ.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Type IV: Incorrect, Type IV hypersensitivity is a delayed reaction mediated by T cells, not antibodies, and is not responsible for hyperacute rejection.

 

Option B. Type III: Incorrect, Type III hypersensitivity involves immune complexes (antigen-antibody complexes) that can deposit in tissues and cause inflammation but is not the mechanism behind hyperacute rejection.

 

Option D. Type I: Incorrect, Type I hypersensitivity is an immediate allergic reaction (like asthma or anaphylaxis) mediated by IgE antibodies, which is different from the antibody-mediated attack on transplanted organs seen in hyperacute rejection.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Type II hypersensitivity is crucial in the context of hyperacute rejection of renal transplants, highlighting the importance of thorough pre-transplant screening for donor-specific antibodies to avoid this rapid and destructive immune response.

questions.text: Which of the following vaccines contains the largest amount of egg protein? [NEET PG 2015]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) Yellow Fever

 

  • Yellow fever vaccine is a live attenuated vaccine prepared from the 17D strain, which is grown in chick embryo and subsequently freeze-dried. 
  • The vaccine contains significant egg protein content, which explains why anaphylaxis reactions have been documented, occurring mainly in individuals with egg allergies. 
  • This vaccine requires careful storage between +5 and -30°C, preferably below zero.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Rabies: Modern rabies vaccines like PCECV (Purified Chick Embryo Cell Vaccine) and PVRV (Purified Vero cell Vaccine) undergo extensive purification processes specifically designed to remove cellular proteins, resulting in lower egg protein content.

 

Option B. MMR: The MMR vaccine uses production methods that result in minimal egg protein in the final product. Egg allergy is not considered a major contraindication for MMR administration.

 

Option C. Influenza: While influenza vaccines are typically produced in eggs, the manufacturing process includes purification steps to reduce egg protein content below that found in yellow fever vaccine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Yellow fever vaccine's production method in chick embryo without extensive protein removal results in higher egg protein content than other vaccines, necessitating caution in individuals with egg allergies.

questions.text: A patient comes to the emergency room with a history of multiple episodes of vomiting. After being administered an intravenous drug for treatment, he develops abnormal movements. Which of the following medications can be used to manage his abnormal movements? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Benzhexol

 

Benzhexol (also known as trihexyphenidyl) is an anticholinergic agent often used to treat extrapyramidal symptoms, which include abnormal involuntary movements. These symptoms can occur as a side effect of D2 blockers like antipsychotics and some antiemetics like metoclopramide that may have been used to treat the vomiting.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hyoscine: This is an antispasmodic and anticholinergic drug mainly used for motion sickness and gastrointestinal spasms. It is not specifically used for treating abnormal movements such as extrapyramidal symptoms.

 

Option B. Cyproheptadine: This is an antihistamine and anticholinergic medication used mainly for allergic reactions. It is not primarily indicated for the treatment of abnormal movements.

 

Option C. Levodopa: This medication is primarily used for treating Parkinson's disease and is not indicated for the treatment of drug-induced abnormal movements unless those symptoms are related to Parkinson’s disease.

 

Therefore, in this patient who developed abnormal movements possibly due to a drug side effect, Benzhexol would be the appropriate medication for managing his symptoms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Benzhexol (trihexyphenidyl) is the drug of choice for managing extrapyramidal symptoms, which include abnormal movements induced by medications such as D2 receptor blockers.

questions.text: What is the maximum period of voluntary self-admission under the Mental Healthcare Act 2017?(NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 30 days

 

Under the Mental Healthcare Act 2017 of India, a person with a mental illness can voluntarily admit themselves to a mental health establishment. The maximum duration for such voluntary admission is up to 30 days. If extended care is needed beyond this period, a fresh admission process is required.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 48 hours: Not the specified duration for voluntary self-admission.

 

Option B. 7 days: Not the maximum duration for voluntary self-admission.

 

Option D. 90 days: Far exceeds the duration mentioned in the act for voluntary self-admission.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Under the Mental Healthcare Act 2017 in India, a person with a mental illness can voluntarily admit themselves to a mental health establishment for a maximum period of 30 days.

 

Reference: Forensic Psychiatry in India, Interface of Indian laws and mental health, 27-28.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male with motor traffic accident with BP 90/60mm Hg. On examination, he was stable with GCS 15/15. The pupil was reactive to light. Tenderness and bruising over the left lower chest wall with petechia were seen. What is the next step? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. eFAST

 

Explanation:

 

The next step in the evaluation of a trauma patient with the given findings is the Extended Focused Assessment with Sonography for Trauma (eFAST). This non-invasive imaging technique is crucial for rapidly identifying free fluid and organ injuries in the abdomen, as well as potential pneumothorax or hemothorax, which are critical in trauma cases. eFAST is used to quickly assess both stable and unstable patients following blunt abdominal trauma, providing immediate information that can dictate further management steps.

 

Details:

 

eFAST Role: This ultrasound examination checks for free intraperitoneal or pericardial fluid and can evaluate the integrity of the pleural spaces.

 

Stability: Despite the patient's low blood pressure, he is neurologically intact (GCS 15/15) and responsive, which allows for an ultrasound examination before more invasive procedures are considered.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Exploratory laparotomy: Generally reserved for patients showing signs of hemodynamic instability after eFAST or when eFAST is positive for intra-abdominal injury needing surgical intervention.

 

Option B. Intubation: Might be necessary if respiratory status worsens or if advanced airway management is required, but the patient’s current stable neurological status does not immediately warrant this.

 

Option D. CECT (Contrast Enhanced CT Scan): Used after eFAST if the patient remains hemodynamically stable and further detailed evaluation of internal injuries is necessary.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Vaccinating pigs is helpful in disease control

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about Japanese encephalitis? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Man acts as the reservoir

 

Humans are the dead-end hosts for the Japanese encephalitis virus.

 

Japanese encephalitis is a viral infection caused by the Japanese encephalitis virus (JEV), which belongs to the Flavivirus family.

 

Symptoms of Japanese encephalitis can range from mild, flu-like illness to severe neurological complications, such as high fever, headache, neck stiffness, disorientation, seizures, paralysis, and even coma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. The disease is transmitted by Culex tritaeniorhynchus and Culex vishnui (common in India) species.

 

Option B. Herons act as reservoir hosts and pigs as amplifier hosts.

 

Option D. The control measures include mosquito control, locating piggeries away from the human dwellings and vaccinating pigs.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Understanding the transmission dynamics of Japanese encephalitis is crucial for implementing effective control measures. While humans can become severely ill from JE, they do not play a significant role in the disease's transmission cycle, emphasizing the importance of controlling mosquito populations and managing amplifier hosts like pigs to reduce the incidence of this potentially deadly disease.

choices.text: Cherry red hypostasis due to CO

questions.text: A family died in a closed room which was full of smoke from woodfire. Which of the following is the finding seen on the body? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cherry red hypostasis due to CO

 

When a fire occurs in a closed space (home), the combustion is incomplete due to limited oxygen. This leads to the production of carbon monoxide (CO). Carbon monoxide binds with hemoglobin in the blood to form carboxyhemoglobin, which imparts a characteristic cherry red color to the hypostasis seen in the body post-mortem. This is a hallmark finding in CO poisoning and is used as a key diagnostic indicator.

 

Additionally, fires in industrial buildings (closed spaces) can produce cyanide due to the combustion of synthetic fibers containing nitrogen. However, for examination purposes, the cherry red color is most commonly associated with carbon monoxide poisoning.
